pr_title: Update SCM to notify listeners if fresh copy of capability is received

timeline.message: Notify listeners when fresh copy of capability is received
Fix an issue in SCM unit tests

timeline.bodyText: It doesn't appear that you usually use tabs to align these param comments (e.g. above retrieveCapability()). I think this should be consistent. There really should be a project style guide where the correct style for this stuff can be noted.
timeline.author: joeljfischer
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -335,11 +335,11 @@ public void onReceived(RPCMessage message) {
 	 * Sets a capability in the cached map. This should only be done when an RPC is received and contains updates to the capability
 	 * that is being cached in the SystemCapabilityManager.
 	 * @param systemCapabilityType the system capability type that will be set
-	 * @param capability the value of the capability that will be set
+	 * @param capability           the value of the capability that will be set

replies.bodyText: Yes, you are right, we don't usually do that. I used Android Studio Reformatter tool to reformat this method. It looks like the tool adds spaces to align the params. I will remove that for consistency.
replies.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText: I think that currently iOS always calls with a cached value even if the value is null. This may be a point to be aligned.
timeline.author: joeljfischer
joeljfischer

replies.bodyText: Forcing an update is not the only case that triggers this logic. If forceUpdate=false, and the cap is not cashed, when we call GetCapablity(), this logic will be triggered. But you are right the comment is a little vague. I will update the comment.
replies.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.author: joeljfischer
joeljfischer

replies.bodyText: Ah, you are right, the test actually asserts that subscribe=false as you mentioned. The comment is wrong. I will update it.
replies.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText:
Currently, iOS calls the listener with a cached value of nil. This may be a point of alignment needed.
Why does it not call with the cached value if we are sending a GetCapability request? Should the && before !shouldSendGetCapabilityRequest be an ||?
timeline.author: joeljfischer
joeljfischer

timeline.message: Add more unit tests for DISPLAYS capability

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            		- if subscribe is true and the HU supports subscriptions, then shouldSubscribe = true
          
          
            
            		- if subscribe is true, then shouldSubscribe = true
          
      
    
    
  

This doesn't appear to be true, it's if subscribe == true, then shouldSubscribe = true.
timeline.author: joeljfischer
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -550,7 +551,13 @@ private void retrieveCapability(final SystemCapabilityType systemCapabilityType,
 		}
 		final GetSystemCapability request = new GetSystemCapability();
 		request.setSystemCapabilityType(systemCapabilityType);
-		// If subscribe is null, then don't change the current subscription status
+
+		/*
+		The subscription flag in the request should be set based on multiple variables:
+		- if subscribe is null (no change), shouldSubscribe = current subscription status
+		- if subscribe is false, then shouldSubscribe = false
+		- if subscribe is true and the HU supports subscriptions, then shouldSubscribe = true

replies.bodyText: But if the HU doesn't support subscriptions, shouldSubscribe will be false right? even if subscribe = true? because we are doing && supportsSubscriptions()
replies.author: bilal-alsharifi
joeljfischer

replies.bodyText: It is actually confusing. I will simplify the condition a bit.
replies.author: bilal-alsharifi

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            		- if subscribe is null (no change), shouldSubscribe = current subscription status
          
          
            
            		- if subscribe is null (no change), shouldSubscribe = current subscription status, or false if the HU does not support subscriptions
timeline.author: joeljfischer
joeljfischer

replies.bodyText: The use of underscores in java is not very common. Except for naming const variables. I prefer the first suggested name as it complies more with Java naming conventions.
replies.author: bilal-alsharifi
